columns.text: In this problem, we need to explain what tools managers can use to track a firmâ€™s claims and what the aging schedule is.

**a)**  One of the most important indicators of a firm's receivables is outstanding accounts. Each company continuously monitors its ACP. If the company is in seasonal business, the ACP will vary throughout the year. However, if the ACP unexpectedly increases, then the company needs to review its receivables in more detail and determine whether customers need more time to pay or some receivables are tlong overdue.  
The second basic tool for monitoring receivables is the  aging schedule.

**b)**   The aging schedule is prepared by the credit department and this schedule contains data on the age of the order, on the total values of the receivables account by days, which are also shown in percentages. Based on that schedule, the firm's credit department will estimate how late his claims are and how worrying those delays are. It all depends on the nature of the claims and the seriousness of the customers.
